title: Luis Liendo
text:
Luis Antonio Liendo Asbún (born February 25, 1978 in <a href="La%20Serena%2C%20Chile">La Serena</a>) is a retired <a href="Chile">Chile</a>an-<a href="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>n <a href="association%20football">football</a> midfielder, who has played in different leagues throughout South America, Europe and North America. He also played for the <a href="Bolivia%20national%20football%20team">Bolivia national team</a>.
Club career.
Liendo began his soccer career in 1997 playing for the <a href="Boca%20Juniors">Boca Juniors</a> reserves team in <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a> then was signed by <a href="Club%20Bol%C3%ADvar">Bolívar</a> in Bolivia.
Liendo had a brief experience with <a href="Real%20Madrid%20Castilla">Real Madrid B</a> in Spain. Shortly after his time in Spain, he was bought by <a href="Ascoli%20Calcio%201898">Ascoli</a> in <a href="Italy">Italy</a>. He also played for <a href="A.S.D.%20Spezia%20Calcio%202008">Spezia</a>, <a href="Novara%20Calcio">Novara</a> and <a href="Gela%20Calcio">Gela</a> in Italy.
After six years of playing in Italy, Liendo relocated to North America where he played for the USL1 team, <a href="Atlanta%20Silverbacks">Atlanta Silverbacks</a> in 2007. After a couple of seasons in the United States, Liendo returned to Bolivia and signed with <a href="La%20Paz%20F.C.">La Paz F.C.</a>. Towards the end of his career he also played for <a href="Universitario%20de%20Sucre">Universitario de Sucre</a> and <a href="Sport%20Boys%20Warnes">Sport Boys Warnes</a>.
International career.
Liendo earned 6 caps for the <a href="Bolivian%20national%20football%20team">Bolivian national team</a> and was called up by his country for several <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">FIFA World Cup qualification</a> matches, but did not make any appearance
Personal life.
Liendo's father, also Luis (born April 1946), played in Argentina, Bolivia and Chile during the 70's and 80's and also played for the <a href="Bolivia%20national%20football%20team">Bolivia national team</a>.
